license.description: De Internationale Creative Commons 4.0 licentie waarbij de gebruiker het werk mag kopiëren, verspreiden en doorgeven en afgeleide werken mag maken onder de voorwaarde: Naamsvermelding, zie http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/.

items.content:
What we accomplished in Week 1

To wrap-up Week 1, Alessandra shares her own takeaway thoughts, to give you an overview of what has been discussed so far in the course.

Learning objectives

Learning objectives

During this week we will cover the basic concepts related to Open and FAIR research data. You will get hands-on experience with open research datasets, and learn to adopt a critical attitude towards Open Science efforts. In the next video lectures we will:

  • introduce research data management and open data,
  • discuss the what, how and why of research data management and open data, and
  • interview Gianfranco Cecconi and Ester Huyer about the European Data Portal.

Completion time (estimation)

For this module the team suggests that you invest approximately 1 hour to watch the video lectures, and 3-4 hours to complete the data management assignment.

Opening your research can provide you with many benefits but can also pose several challenges. To manage this, as Anneke Zuiderwijk explains in the video below, a resource data management plan can be beneficial.

prompt.body: What do you need to take into account when applying effective data management? Select all that apply.

content.body: The nature of the data you are collecting
How you can safely store your data
Who will be able to access and manipulate the data
How to document your data so others understand it

For effective data management you need to take into account a lot of things. Among others, you need to be aware of the nature of the data that you will be collecting, how you can safely store it, who can access it and who can manipulate it. Also, you need to be able to document your data in such a way so that others can understand and reuse it.

items.content: Data description is an important part of the data management plan with which you can help others to understand your data.

prompt.body: Which statements about data management planning are correct? Select all that apply.

content.body: A data management plan does not help enhancing research integrity
A data management plan can make sure you can understand and reuse your data

Making a data management plan is an excellent example of research integrity. So by making a good data management plan you are inherently showing research integrity.
The data management plan includes the purpose for which the data are being collected or created, but also which methodologies are used to compile or derive raw data. This makes it easier for you to keep track of what data you have generated. This helps you to understand your data, which makes you a more efficient and effective researcher.
Your research might be funded by a party that requires you to present a data management plan, but this is not always the case. It will help you to show funders that you are meeting their requirements.
A data management plan can make you a more efficient and effective researcher

Making a data management plan is an excellent example of research integrity. So by making a good data management plan you are inherently showing research integrity.
The data management plan includes the purpose for which the data are being collected or created, but also which methodologies are used to compile or derive raw data. This makes it easier for you to keep track of what data you have generated. This helps you to understand your data, which makes you a more efficient and effective researcher.
Your research might be funded by a party that requires you to present a data management plan, but this is not always the case. It will help you to show funders that you are meeting their requirements.
A data management plan is always a prerequisite for meeting funder requirements

items.content: Properly documented data will ensure maximum re-usability. Providing proper data quality increases the understandability of your data for your colleagues. Have you ever created a Readme.txt file? Anneke explains more next.

prompt.body:
Which of the following statements are true?

Statement I: Metadata is data that describes data. Metadata can be collected or generated in the form of a database or as an xml file that follows certain international standards.

Statement II: Standards for metadata vary from discipline to discipline.

content.body: Statement I and II are both true

Metadata is used to describe data. Metadata can be embedded in a data file or could be a set of descriptors that are added to a dataset at the moment of publishing it. In both cases, metadata helps to make data findable and allow others to understand the data.
Some disciplines have created and use metadata standards which facilitate the description of data(sets) in a consensus manner. Those standards differ from one discipline to another according to the type of data and the way they are collected.
Statement I is true and statement II is false
Statement I is false and statement II i strue
Statement I and II are both false

prompt.body:
Indicate whether the following statement is true or false:

The Digital Curation Centre (DCC) provides an overview of metadata standards organized by discipline. If your discipline is not included here, there is no general information for you to learn about metadata standards.

content.body: True
False

In order to provide metadata standards for disciplines that have not yet settled on a metadata standard, and for those repositories that work with data across disciplines, The General Research Data section on the webpage links to information about broader metadata standards that have been adapted to suit the needs of research data.

items.content:
Useful websites

We have collected a number of useful links for you.

You can find some practical information on file naming conventions at the website of Purdue:"Data Management for Undergraduate Researchers: File Naming Conventions" by Purdue University Libraries

Here is a link to 10 rules for file and folder naming best practice: "Folder and File Naming Convention - 10 Rules for Best Practice" by eXadox

Also, there are links on how to structure and organize your folders, providing you with best practices for setting up a good folder structure: "Introducing a basic way to develop manageable, easy-to-use folder structures" by Extensis is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

This other link provides more information on how to set up a folder hierarchy, naming conventions and metadata and keyword strategies: "Digital Asset Management Best Practices Guide" by Extensis is licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0
Considering your data storage and backup strategy in advance removes the risk of losing your research.

prompt.body:
Which of the following statements are true?

Statement I: Any remote or cloud storage service can be used to store all types of data.

Statement II: The amount of back-ups that are needed is dependent on how important your data are and how often they change.

content.body: I and II are both true
I and II are both not true
I is true and II is not true
I is not true and II is true

Services such as Google Drive and Dropbox are not appropriate to store sensitive data therefore a different solution needs to be found for this as you as a researcher are responsible for the safe storage of your data.
Making backups is important to ensure that you do not lose important parts of your research. Therefore making backups of the most important data or of documents which explain how you arrived at the data is very useful.

heading.content: 2.5 Legal and ethical requirement of data access

items.content: All data is subject to legal and ethical requirements. Therefore it is important to think about access to the data, and to define this in your research data management plan. Anneke will tell you more in the video below.

prompt.body:
What do you as a researcher need to consider when looking at the legal and ethical requirements of your research?

Select all that apply.

content.body: Your research discipline
The required security level for your data

Different types of data bring about different limitations for the storage and access of them. Therefore you as a researcher need to decide on what level of security the data you are working with needs and how this affects your research.
Not all data can be accessed from a remote location due to its characteristics. For instance, personal or sensitive data need higher levels of security.
In every research project, multiple people may need to be able to require access to the data, possibly with different privileges.
Other researchers may leave when a project has finished or when they start working on something else. What happens to the data and access by these persons can be specified in your research data management plan beforehand.
If remote access to your data is necessary
Whether your data needs to be accessed by different people
The amount of backups needed for your data
What will happeen to the sccess to your data when someone leaves the project

items.content: To ensure that your data will be reused you need to share your data. One way to do so is through a data repository.

prompt.body: Which of the following statements is true? If you are re-using and sharing a dataset that is openly available, you should take care of:

content.body: Nothing, if it is openly available I can re-use it as I want
Look for the licence or terms of use associated to the dataset to know how the dataset can be re-used

Open means that the dataset is free to reuse, so you do not need to ask for permission to reuse the dataset. However, some open licenses might limit you in editing or sharing the dataset. For example, the license might limit you from publishing a derivative of the original dataset. There is also a license that prevents commercial use of datasets. As long as you stick to these license prerequisites, you do not need to ask for permission

prompt.body:
Sometimes a data repository allows you to choose between different access conditions. Which of the following statements are true?

Statement I: Data shared with a CC0 license can be freely used, modified and shared.

Statement II: Sometimes you can request an embargo period to be imposed on your data, which implies that your data is not accessible up to the date that you specify up to a maximum of ten years.

content.body: Statement I and II are both true
Statement I is true and statement II is false
Open means free to access and reuse by anyone. Some repositories offer the option to put the data under embargo; the length of that period varies by repository.
Statement I is false and statement II is true
Statement I and II are both false

items.content: At the end of your research you need to decide what data to preserve, what to deposit, and in what way you will archive your data. As before, follow Anneke's explanation.

prompt.body:
Which of the following statements are true?

Statement I: It is necessary to preserve all your data if this is needed to reproduce your research.

Statement II: If future work will be based on the data, the data should be preserved.

content.body: Statement I and II are both true

According to best practices, datasets underlying research should be reproducible. This is crucial for other researchers to understand how you reached certain decisions in your study and how you interpreted the data. You may regret disposing of certain datasets if you want to use these datasets to build on for future research. If you are not sure whether you will conduct future research based on the previously collected data, it is better to preserve the data.
Statement I is true and Statement II is false
Statement I is false and statement II is true
Statement I and II are both false

items.content: It is good practice to add a section to the resource data management plan about the data responsibilities and resources in which you ellaborate who was responsible for what and how you securely stored your data.

prompt.body:
Indicate whether the following statement is true or false:

It is a good reflective exercise to think about data management responsibilities and resources after conducting the data collection.

content.body: True
False

Explanation
In a PhD project you are probably yourself responsible for the data management but for collaborative projects where other researchers are involved someone else may be responsible. Doing this exercise beforehand ensures that best practices regarding research data management are in place and that an efficient workflow can be established.

sections.title: 2.5 Legal and ethical requirement of data access
